messageBody:
Just some responses to statements from Curt and JBR...

In response to Curt Sampson:

> Why futz about with special tools when they're completely unnecessary?

If some tools don't support your way of programming, just don't
use those tools. Please consider, others may have different
ways to do things. I don't think there is THE right way that
fits everything and everyone. Choose what fit's your needs
and don't stop looking for ways to improve.

I've tried to program exactly the way you described. (I did this
months ago.) It just didn't fit me that much. (Please remember,
the difference is only in the way of sketching and this depends
on the support by the IDE one uses, too.)


In response to J. B. Rainsberger:

> ...For Customer Tests, I would never expect to find a CT by
> looking for a method name; I would look for the name of a use case or
> transaction script or feature.

I agree with you. That's what I ment with my PS statement
at the bottom of that email.

> >JUnitDoclet allows re-generating, so it's not much work
> >to keep tests and app in sync.
>
> Regenerating what? Does it regenerate test stubs?

Yes, stubs are _regenerated_and_merged_ according to the
new structure of the application.Most of the tests are placed
in the right spot and the tool points you to the few others,
that have been affected by the change in the application if
they could not been handled automatically.
_No_test_gets_lost._
If one does that as part of refactoring, it's very easy to
manage, since refactoring is done in small steps.

> Do I need to reimplement my test?!

NO. Definitely not.
(I would like to write this in very large letters. :)

Regards,

Steffen Gemkow
